class rktoolkit.models.graph.GraphMask(*, nodeMasks: dict = {}, edgeMasks: dict = {})¶

Bases: pydantic.main.BaseModel

Graph masks are similar to numpy masks. They represent a masking of graph elements and are ultimately what the filter functions are generating.

class rktoolkit.models.graph.HierarchicalGraph(*, nodes: rktoolkit.models.graph.Node = [], edges: rktoolkit.models.graph.Edge = [], root: rktoolkit.models.graph.TreeNode)¶

Bases: rktoolkit.models.graph.GraphModel

A Hierarchical Graph is a subset of the general graph in which all elements are directed.

class rktoolkit.models.graph.Node(*, id: str = None, name: str = (None), value: float = None, attributes: dict = {})¶

Bases: pydantic.main.BaseModel

attributes: Optional[dict]¶

A node represents a distinct object in a graph

A subclass of node that speiciflcally is used in DAG creation. It has a couple features a normal node doesn’t have, such as checking boundary conditions and an executing function for data transformation

id: Optional[str]¶
name: Optional[str]¶
value: Optional[float]¶
class rktoolkit.models.graph.RKModel(*, mask: rktoolkit.models.graph.GraphMask = None, hgraph: rktoolkit.models.graph.HierarchicalGraph = None, links: List[rktoolkit.models.graph.Edge] = None, location: List[float] = None)¶

Bases: pydantic.main.BaseModel

An RK-Model is the core data-structure that can be manifested in an RK-Diagram or interpreted.

RK-Models are different from most models due to a number of important features:

  • HierarchicalGraph(h) => a heierarchical graph of features. Which features

have a directional relationship with eachother - Mask (mask) => A graph mask. Represents a masking function on top of the Hierarchical Graph - Links => Links just edges. They can be computed with a Linkage Function - Locatoin => A global position for reference. When plotting an rkmodel against other rk-models, this positions the rk-models relative to eachtother

complete() → bool¶
hgraph: rktoolkit.models.graph.HierarchicalGraph¶
links: List[rktoolkit.models.graph.Edge]¶
location: List[float]¶
mask: rktoolkit.models.graph.GraphMask¶

rktoolkit.models.linkage module¶

class rktoolkit.models.linkage.LinkageFunction¶

Bases: object

A linkage function takes in a list of nodes and returns a list of edges

There are mnay different types of linkage functions.

For example, see https://pypi.org/project/fastcluster/ as an example

We have in the LIGO example, a linkage function with Euclidean distance defined.

link(nodes: List[rktoolkit.models.graph.Node]) → List[rktoolkit.models.graph.Edge]¶
